conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the relationship between the accelerations of Car A and Car B.
The graph shows two curves, A and B, representing the velocities of Car A and Car B respectively over time from t = 0 to t = t1.
Car A starts with a lower velocity v1 and increases to v2 over time.
Car B starts with a higher velocity v2 and decreases to v1 over time.
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the tangent to the curve.
For Car A, the curve is concave up, indicating that the slope (acceleration) is decreasing over time.
For Car B, the curve is concave down, indicating that the slope (acceleration) is becoming more negative over time.
In the second image, the red lines are tangent lines at different points on the curves, representing instantaneous acceleration.
For Car A, the tangent lines become less steep (less positive) as time progresses, indicating a decreasing positive acceleration.
For Car B, the tangent lines become steeper (more negative) as time progresses, indicating an increasing negative acceleration.
At any given moment, the slope of the tangent to Car A’s curve is less steep than the slope of the tangent to Car B’s curve.
The magnitude of the acceleration of Car A is less than that of Car B at any instant during the period from t = 0 to t = t1.
The magnitude of the acceleration of Car A is less than the magnitude of the acceleration of Car B during the period from t = 0 to t = t1.
